news_items.title: A tool to create Flutter projects more efficiently
news_items.author: John Smith
news_items.content:
## ðŸ§ª Project Overview

![quattro research logo](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Logo_placeholder_image.png/600px-Logo_placeholder_image.png)

Founded in **2004**, **quattro research** develops intuitive software that empowers digital scientific workflows. Their **Laboratory Information Management Systems (LIMS)** â€” such as **quattro/CM**, **quattro/LJ**, and **quattro/BR** â€” manage and analyze complex chemical and biological data.

---

![Team Collaboration](https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1632179002215-f5c8d5dcf35b)

To scale quickly and meet growing client demand, quattro research partnered with **unicrew** to strengthen their engineering team with skilled developers who could integrate seamlessly and boost project velocity.

---

## ðŸš§ Key Challenges

![Challenges](https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1573164713347-df1e1f69a3f2)

- **Scalability Requirements** â€“ Needed to scale fast without lowering code quality.
- **Complex UI Needs** â€“ Required a responsive UI for large molecular datasets.
- **Scientific Data Presentation** â€“ Flexible visualization in dynamic grids and forms.
- **Modern Security Protocols** â€“ Needed secure access management (OAuth, JWT).
- **High-Performance Rendering** â€“ For complex molecule structure visualization.

---

## âœ… Solution

### ðŸ”¹ React-Based UI

![React UI](https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1581091012184-5c2bca6f3bb6)

Designed and implemented a performant, intuitive React frontend for handling complex molecule data structures.

---

### ðŸ”¹ Configurable Data Framework

![Grid System](https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1645051915681-183d5f30ef0a)

Developed a flexible framework allowing scientists to customize data views using dynamic **grids** and **forms**.

---

### ðŸ”¹ Secure Authentication

![Security](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:720/format:webp/0*PRZcNPDVe2z5n7kO)

Integrated **OAuth** and **JWT** for robust and modern authentication & authorization standards.

---

### ðŸ”¹ Molecule Visualization

![Molecule Viewer](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:720/format:webp/0*PRZcNPDVe2z5n7kO)

Delivered advanced visualization tools for rendering large and complex molecule structures efficiently.

---

## ðŸ‘¥ Collaboration Snapshot

![Unicrew Team](https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1581091870622-df42a3f9808b)

**unicrew** assembled a full-stack development team with expertise in:
- `.NET`, `Java`, `PHP`, `Laravel`
- `JavaScript`, `React`, `Vue`

They worked in **agile sprints** alongside quattro researchâ€™s internal team to maintain alignment, speed, and flexibility.

---

## ðŸŽ¯ Results

![Success](https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1581093588401-99a6f43db2a9)

- **âš¡ Faster Development** â€“ Accelerated product delivery timelines.
- **ðŸŽ¨ Better Usability** â€“ UI tailored for scientific users.
- **ðŸ” Improved Security** â€“ OAuth and JWT integration.
- **ðŸ”¬ Enhanced Visualization** â€“ Clarity in molecule data exploration.
- **ðŸ¤ Ongoing Partnership** â€“ Sustained collaboration with quattro research.

---

> _"unicrew's developers integrated seamlessly with our team, demonstrating professionalism and a deep understanding of our needs. Their contributions have been invaluable."_  
> â€” **Dr. Bernhard Schirm**, Managing Director

[ðŸ”— View Full Review](https://example.com/review)

---

news_items.title: Which LLM Really Handles Complex 3D Coding? A Stress Test You Wonâ€™t See in Demos
news_items.author: Dr Mukhtiar Ahmad
news_items.content:
I gave GPT-5, Claude Sonnet 4, Gemini Flash 2.5, DeepSeek DeepThink (R1), and Amazon Kiro the same complex coding task: a 3D neural network simulation in Three.js. Only one model came close to production-level quality.


##  Why I Ran This Experiment
Most LLM reviews show simple tasks: â€œwrite a landing pageâ€ or â€œgenerate a Python script.â€ But those donâ€™t really tell us how these models behave under **real production-like complexity.**
*I wanted to see how these models perform when asked to tackle a tightly constrained, visually verifiable, and mathematically precise coding challenge â€” one where mistakes are immediately obvious.*
So I wrote a **prompt about 1,500 tokens long,** spelling out every requirement of a **3D neural network visualization in Three.js.**
![Dashboard](/blogs-images/3d-coding-challenge.png)

The article below includes only a structured summary of those requirements (for readability). But make no mistake: the actual spec was meticulous, covering exact math formulas, timing phases, firing rules, and strict boundary enforcement.
## The Benchmark Problem

### Task (summary of original prompt):

Create a professional 3D neural network visualization using **Three.js** that demonstrates dynamic shape morphing, neural activity simulation, interactive camera controls, and perfect geometric containment of all neural elements.

---

## Highlights of the Requirements

### ðŸ”¹ Shapes & Morphing
- Cycle through 5 shapes in strict order: **Sphere â†’ Cone â†’ Cube â†’ Pyramid â†’ Cylinder**  
- Smooth morphing transitions, infinite loop  

### ðŸ”¹ Neurons & Connections
- Exactly **1,200 neurons** (white wireframe spheres)  
- At least **3 connections per neuron**, proximity-based  
- **Zero tolerance** for neurons or links outside the shape boundary  

### ðŸ”¹ Activity Simulation
- Random neurons fire every **150ms (~1.5%)**
- Red â€œmeteor effectâ€ travels along links.
- Destination neuron glows red and scales 3x for 800ms, then resets.
### ðŸ”¹Camera & Interaction
- Interactive rotation with mouse; gentle auto-rotation fallback.
- Cinematic zoom-in (3s) and zoom-out (3s), synced with morph transitions.
- Smooth easing, no jerky movements.

### ðŸ”¹Performance
- 60fps target.
- Memory-efficient cleanup of effects.
- Responsive resizing.
- Single HTML file with Three.js via CDN.

In short: **a professional-grade animation system** that would expose weaknesses in any modelâ€™s reasoning or code structure.

## The Test Setup

I tested five LLMs:

- **Chat interfaces:** GPT-5, Claude Sonnet 4, Gemini Flash 2.5, DeepSeek DeepThink (R1)  
- **Software development environment:** Amazon Kiro  

Every model received the same requirements. I evaluated them on **accuracy, containment, animation quality, and refinement potential**.

---

## Results by Model

### GPT-5 (Chat UI)

GPT-5 generated workable code, but with serious issues:

- Neurons consistently **leaked outside shape boundaries**.  
- Connections were extended incorrectly.  
- Neuron firing lacked polish and synchronization.  
- Even with multiple refinement prompts, shapes stayed messy.  

Using **GPT-5 Agents** (longer reasoning) prolonged the process but didnâ€™t fix alignment errors â€” cones inverted, pyramids misplaced, neurons still out of bounds.

**Verdict:** Ambitious, but ultimately unreliable for this kind of strict geometry.

### Claude Sonnet 4 (Chat UI)

Claude performed better than GPT-5:

- More structured output and closer adherence to requirements.  
- Shapes looked cleaner, firing slightly more naturally.  

Butâ€¦

- Neurons still escaped boundaries.  
- Links didnâ€™t always update correctly.  
- After 5â€“7 refinement prompts, things improved, but never reached spec.  

**Verdict:** Better discipline than GPT-5, but still not production-ready.  

---

### Gemini Flash 2.5 (Chat UI)

When given the prompt, Gemini replied with:

*I am unable to generate a complete and functional HTML file with the complex Three.js code youâ€™ve requested. My capabilities are limited to providing information and generating text or images, and I cannot create a fully-coded, executable web page.*

**Verdict:** Refreshingly honest, but ultimately a non-result for this test.
### DeepSeek DeepThink (R1) (Chat UI)

Marketed as a â€œthinkingâ€ model, DeepSeek showed the same execution gaps as GPT and Claude:

- Out-of-bounds neurons.  
- Misaligned links.  
- Firing animations lacked precision.
  
Reasoning ability didnâ€™t translate into technical correctness here.  

**Verdict:** Same flaws, different branding.  

---

### Amazon Kiro (Software Dev Environment)

This was the surprise.  

Unlike the chat UIs, Kiro didnâ€™t just dump code. It followed a structured development workflow:

1. Converted my long prompt into a Markdown requirements doc.  
2. Translated that into a design specification.  
3. Broke it down into a task list.  
4. Then generated the implementation.  

The first attempt missed a few requirements. But when I asked:  

> Are you sure you implemented all the requirements?  

Kiro did something no other model did:  

- It checked its work against the requirements list.  
- Found the gaps.  
- Fixed them in the next iteration with a single prompt.  

The final result hit about **95% of the full spec**.  

**Verdict:** The only LLM-based system in this test that was able to implement all the requirements correctly.  
## Final Rankings  

ðŸ¥‡ **Amazon Kiro** â†’ Clear winner. Met nearly all requirements with minimal prompting.  
ðŸ¥ˆ **Claude Sonnet 4.0** â†’ Strong attempt, but too much manual refinement needed.  
ðŸ¥‰ **GPT-5** â†’ Ambitious but messy and inconsistent.  
ðŸŽ­ **DeepSeek Think (R1)** â†’ Same flaws as GPT/Claude, despite â€œreasoningâ€ claims.  
ðŸš« **Gemini Flash 2.5** â†’ Did not attempt implementation.  

---

## Takeaways  

1. **Long, detailed prompts expose model weaknesses.**  
   The 1,500-token spec I provided was deliberately precise, and most models struggled to stay within those constraints.  

2. **Chat UIs arenâ€™t enough for production-level tasks.**  
   GPT, Claude, DeepSeek, and Gemini behaved like â€œhelpers.â€ They donâ€™t enforce discipline unless you spoon-feed corrections for hours.  

3. **Requirement verification is the difference-maker.**  
   Amazon Kiro stood out because it didnâ€™t just generate code â€” it cross-checked requirements, found gaps, and corrected them. Thatâ€™s what made it succeed where others failed.  

---

## Closing Thoughts  

This experiment convinced me of something bigger:  

Future LLMs wonâ€™t just be about being â€œsmarter.â€ Theyâ€™ll need to adopt structured engineering workflows â€” breaking problems down, checking against specs, and iterating systematically.  

Because in real-world coding, intelligence without verification isnâ€™t enough.  

And for now, **Kiro is the only LLM-based system Iâ€™ve tested that was able to implement all the requirements correctly.**  

---

**Note:** Some of the content is AI-generated.
news_items.description:
This article is not about coffee; itâ€™s about how user interactions change and adapt, how generative AI.

Using **GPT-5 Agents** (longer reasoning) prolonged the process but didnâ€™t fix alignment errors â€” cones inverted, pyramids misplaced, neurons still out of bounds.

**Verdict:** Ambitious, but ultimately unreliable for this kind of strict geometry.
*I am unable to generate a complete and functional HTML file with the complex Three.js code youâ€™ve requested. My capabilities are limited to providing information and generating text or images, and I cannot create a fully-coded, executable web page.*

news_items.description: Is Android 15 released?  Various developer previews and beta versions of Android 15 have been released so far.

news_items.title: BLA delivers quality according to world standards
news_items.author: John Smith
news_items.content:
## Whatâ€™s new with Android 15?
Android 15 introduces enhanced privacy controls, new APIs for better performance and user experience, and advanced camera features like **Low Light Boost**. It also deprecates older technologies like **WebSQL**, making way for more modern solutions like **IndexedDB**.
## Is Android 15 released?
Various developer previews and beta versions of Android 15 have been released so far. The final launch is expected to occur sometime in the **fall of 2024**.

## How does Android 15 address app compatibility and backward compatibility issues?
Android 15 includes several measures to ensure app compatibility and backward compatibility, such as:
- Detailed documentation on behavior changes
- New feature support
- Tools like the **Android Compatibility Test Suite (CTS)**

These ensure that apps remain functional and performant on the new platform while still supporting older versions where necessary.

## What are the benefits of the improved camera APIs in Android 15 for app developers?
The improved camera APIs provide:
- Greater control over camera hardware
- Real-time effects
- Improved HDR processing
- Better integration with machine learning algorithms

These capabilities help developers create advanced camera experiences like:

- Augmented reality applications
- Advanced photo/video editing features
## How does Android 15 improve app performance on older devices?
Android 15 offers:
- Optimized memory management
- Enhanced rendering pipelines

These improvements ensure apps run smoothly even on devices with limited hardware resources.

---

## References

- [First Android 15 Developer Preview](https://android-developers.googleblog.com/2024/02/first-developer-preview-android15.html)
- [Android 15 Features Overview](https://developer.android.com/about/versions/15/features)
- [Android Developers Blog](https://android-developers.googleblog.com)
- [Android Developers Official Site](https://developer.android.com)
